elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new compound of (NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3.5DMF]) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,1′,4′,1″,4″,1‴-quaterphenyl-3,5,3‴,5‴-tetracarboxylic acid 1,3,5-benzenetrisbenzoate) was synthesized and characterized. The coordination polymer shows an unusual 4,8-connected 3D net with (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology. The incorporation of the drug 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) into the desolvated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was around 22.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.% per gram of dehydrated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. 5-Fu is released in a highly controlled and progressive fashion with 92% of the drug released after 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The result from this work provides a new avenue for MOF to be used as potential drug delivery.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
A new compound of (NH2(CH3)2[Zn3(L)2·3.5DMF]) (1) (H4L=1,1′,4′,1″,4″,1‴-quaterphenyl-3,5,3‴,5‴-tetracarboxylic acid 1,3,5-benzenetrisbenzoate) was synthesized and characterized. The coordination polymer shows an unusual 4,8-connected 3D net with (46)2(412·612·84) topology. The incorporation of the drug 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) into the desolvated 1 was around 22.5wt.% per gram of dehydrated 1. 5-Fu is released in a highly controlled and progressive fashion with 92% of the drug released after 120h. The result from this work provides a new avenue for MOF to be used as potential drug delivery.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">An unusual 4,8-connected 3D net with (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology has been synthesized. 5-Fu is released in a highly controlled and progressive fashion with 92% of the drug released after 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0020" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0050" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the first example of (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">It incorporates the drug 5-FU with 22.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The total drug could release about 92% after 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the first example of (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">It incorporates the drug 5-FU with 22.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The total drug could release about 92% after 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The design and synthesis of porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are now of great interest due to the significance of potential new applications as functional materials . Particularly, MOFs as drug-delivery vehicles are highly desirable in view of their large loadings of drugs, and biodegradability . Thus far, Férey's group first described promising adsorption and release properties of ibuprofen on non-toxic porous iron(III)-based MOFs , whereas Lin et al. also reported a Pt-based drug at the nanoscale by grafting it as one precursor for creating the framework of a polymer . Latterly, Horcajada and his co-workers have found that some interesting porous crystallized nano-MOFs can adsorb and release several drugs, taking as non-toxic drug carriers . Until now, only a few of MOFs allow high amounts of drugs to be loaded, with a complete delivery time range from 6 to 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
An unusual 4,8-connected 3D net with (46)2(412·612·84) topology has been synthesized. 5-Fu is released in a highly controlled and progressive fashion with 92% of the drug released after 120h.





Highlights



•
Compound 1 shows the first example of (46)2(412·612·84) topology.


•
It incorporates the drug 5-FU with 22.5wt.%.


•
The total drug could release about 92% after 120h.



Compound 1 shows the first example of (46)2(412·612·84) topology.
It incorporates the drug 5-FU with 22.5wt.%.
The total drug could release about 92% after 120h.
The design and synthesis of porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are now of great interest due to the significance of potential new applications as functional materials . Particularly, MOFs as drug-delivery vehicles are highly desirable in view of their large loadings of drugs, and biodegradability . Thus far, Férey's group first described promising adsorption and release properties of ibuprofen on non-toxic porous iron(III)-based MOFs , whereas Lin et al. also reported a Pt-based drug at the nanoscale by grafting it as one precursor for creating the framework of a polymer . Latterly, Horcajada and his co-workers have found that some interesting porous crystallized nano-MOFs can adsorb and release several drugs, taking as non-toxic drug carriers . Until now, only a few of MOFs allow high amounts of drugs to be loaded, with a complete delivery time range from 6 to 23days .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Recently, the concept of the secondary building units (SBUs) as the nodes was devised by Yaghi and his co-workers . However, it is still difficult to get the SBUs with a high coordination number larger than 8 via organic ligand and multi-nuclear clusters. In coordination frameworks, the metal cations and carboxylate ligands can form a range of multinuclear nodes with predefined geometries, which will eliminate the typical drawback to MOFs with large pores occurring at different interpenetrations .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, the concept of the secondary building units (SBUs) as the nodes was devised by Yaghi and his co-workers . However, it is still difficult to get the SBUs with a high coordination number larger than 8 via organic ligand and multi-nuclear clusters. In coordination frameworks, the metal cations and carboxylate ligands can form a range of multinuclear nodes with predefined geometries, which will eliminate the typical drawback to MOFs with large pores occurring at different interpenetrations .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">After careful consideration, herein, we chose the tetracarboxylate ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L with zinc salt to construct an unusual 4,8-connected 3D net with (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology based on a trinulcear unit . The incorporation of the drug 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) into the desolvated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was around 22.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.% per gram of dehydrated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. 5-Fu is released in a highly controlled and progressive fashion with 92% of the drug released after 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: After careful consideration, herein, we chose the tetracarboxylate ligand H4L with zinc salt to construct an unusual 4,8-connected 3D net with (46)2(412·612·84) topology based on a trinulcear unit . The incorporation of the drug 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) into the desolvated 1 was around 22.5wt.% per gram of dehydrated 1. 5-Fu is released in a highly controlled and progressive fashion with 92% of the drug released after 120h.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains three Zn atoms, two L ligands, two NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> cations and solvated DMF molecules. a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor> shows the stick view of the local octahedral geometries around the Zn(II) atoms. The center Zn1 is six-coordinated by six O atoms through three symmetric carboxylate groups, while Zn2 is also six-coordinated by six different O atoms from four separated carboxylate groups. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> clusters coordinated to carboxylate groups from eight different L ligands (b). The ligands in turn coordinate to four different Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> clusters, generating a complicated 3D network with 1D channel of 14.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> diagonally (c). From the topological view, it has 4,8-connected 3D net with (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). It is interesting to note that topology in this title compound can be considered to be derived from the basic net Flu (fluorite) by splitting each 4-c vertex into two 3-c vertices as described in  (see ESI<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>† for detailed topological information on the Flu (fluorite)) . The identification of the nets and computation of their ideal symmetry are performed through the program <ce:italic>Systre</ce:italic>, and the names of the net (three-letter codes) are assigned to GMC (GMC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Guangdong Medical Colleague) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> by the database <ce:italic>RCSR</ce:italic> (see supporting information for detailed topological information on <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) . It is an unusual topology based on (4,8)-connected mode. To the best of our knowledge, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> represents the first example of (4,8)-connected node with such topology.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The asymmetric unit of 1 contains three Zn atoms, two L ligands, two NH2(CH3)2 cations and solvated DMF molecules. a shows the stick view of the local octahedral geometries around the Zn(II) atoms. The center Zn1 is six-coordinated by six O atoms through three symmetric carboxylate groups, while Zn2 is also six-coordinated by six different O atoms from four separated carboxylate groups. The structure of 1 contains Zn3 clusters coordinated to carboxylate groups from eight different L ligands (b). The ligands in turn coordinate to four different Zn3 clusters, generating a complicated 3D network with 1D channel of 14.2×14.5Å2 diagonally (c). From the topological view, it has 4,8-connected 3D net with (46)2(412·612·84) topology (
). It is interesting to note that topology in this title compound can be considered to be derived from the basic net Flu (fluorite) by splitting each 4-c vertex into two 3-c vertices as described in  (see ESI† for detailed topological information on the Flu (fluorite)) . The identification of the nets and computation of their ideal symmetry are performed through the program Systre, and the names of the net (three-letter codes) are assigned to GMC (GMC=Guangdong Medical Colleague) in 1 by the database RCSR (see supporting information for detailed topological information on 1) . It is an unusual topology based on (4,8)-connected mode. To the best of our knowledge, 1 represents the first example of (4,8)-connected node with such topology.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Overall, the framework structure is anionic with (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations (dimethylformamide is not stable in the presence of strong bases or strong acids and is easily hydrolyzed affording formic acid and dimethylamine) as well as DMF residing in the channels, as determined by TGA (Fig. S1). The <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> of crystallinity and incorporation of the drug molecule during adsorption process are confirmed by XRD and IR (see Fig. S2 and Fig. S3) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Overall, the framework structure is anionic with (CH3)2NH2
+ cations (dimethylformamide is not stable in the presence of strong bases or strong acids and is easily hydrolyzed affording formic acid and dimethylamine) as well as DMF residing in the channels, as determined by TGA (Fig. S1). The 1 of crystallinity and incorporation of the drug molecule during adsorption process are confirmed by XRD and IR (see Fig. S2 and Fig. S3) .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">UV–vis absorption spectroscopy has been used to determine the effective storage capacity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (see ESI<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>†). To reach a maximal drug loading, 5-FU to porous solid relative ratio and contact time were tested. After the trivial tests, the best results were achieved when <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ was soaked for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL ethanol solution with a 5-FU to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ weight ratio of 1:3. It showed remarkable 5-FU adsorption and the loading content was measured to be 22.5%. This result is close to the Busulfan loading in the MIL-100 . But it is so much lower than that of Cu(pi)-PEG5k polymer reported by Zhou and his-coworkers . Therefore, it can be concluded that some of the total pore volume has been used for occupying of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
UV–vis absorption spectroscopy has been used to determine the effective storage capacity of 1 (see ESI†). To reach a maximal drug loading, 5-FU to porous solid relative ratio and contact time were tested. After the trivial tests, the best results were achieved when 1′ was soaked for 3days in a 20mL ethanol solution with a 5-FU to 1′ weight ratio of 1:3. It showed remarkable 5-FU adsorption and the loading content was measured to be 22.5%. This result is close to the Busulfan loading in the MIL-100 . But it is so much lower than that of Cu(pi)-PEG5k polymer reported by Zhou and his-coworkers . Therefore, it can be concluded that some of the total pore volume has been used for occupying of (CH3)2NH2
+ cations.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Drug release experiments were taken by dialyzing the drug-loaded <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the PBS buffer solution (PBS<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>phosphate buffered saline pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.4) at 37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C . The delivery of 5-FU occurred within a week and 92% of the loaded drug was released (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). 5-FU@ <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ exhibits a slow release in PBS and approximately 50% of the drug was released at the early stage (30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h), then, a more stable release of smaller dosage occurred for one day. After 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, a much burst release curve generates up to 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, such fast-release may result from the degradation of the partial structure, which was confirmed by XRD patterns (Fig. S2). The hydrogen bonded interactions between 5-FU and free cation may lead to this slow release.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Drug release experiments were taken by dialyzing the drug-loaded 1 in the PBS buffer solution (PBS=phosphate buffered saline pH7.4) at 37°C . The delivery of 5-FU occurred within a week and 92% of the loaded drug was released (
). 5-FU@ 1′ exhibits a slow release in PBS and approximately 50% of the drug was released at the early stage (30h), then, a more stable release of smaller dosage occurred for one day. After 72h, a much burst release curve generates up to 10h, such fast-release may result from the degradation of the partial structure, which was confirmed by XRD patterns (Fig. S2). The hydrogen bonded interactions between 5-FU and free cation may lead to this slow release.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In conclusion, a new 3D coordination polymer exhibiting a 3D unusual (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) topology has been synthesized. Moreover, the results of the adsorption and delivery of the drug provide a new avenue on the application of this kind of polymer. Further research about this area is ongoing in our group.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a new 3D coordination polymer exhibiting a 3D unusual (46)2(412·612·84) topology has been synthesized. Moreover, the results of the adsorption and delivery of the drug provide a new avenue on the application of this kind of polymer. Further research about this area is ongoing in our group.

<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(for all data)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1864. GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.097. CCDC: 1042673. The activated samples were prepared by soaking the as-synthesized samples in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH for three days, then in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> for three days and subsequent heating at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under high vacuum for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h to remove the free DMF molecules.</ce:simple-para>

2(for all data)=0.1864. GOF=1.097. CCDC: 1042673. The activated samples were prepared by soaking the as-synthesized samples in CH3OH for three days, then in CH2Cl2 for three days and subsequent heating at 120°C under high vacuum for 10h to remove the free DMF molecules.

metadata.title: A new (4,8)-connected topological MOF as potential drug delivery
